captions.text:
I want to tell you a story about
Renault, or "Renoh," or

"Renawlt," or however you say
it where you come from.

Renault has always been best
known as a maker of
affordable, interesting cars.

But about four years ago, the
world changed for Renault.

It came under enormous pressure
from emerging Korean

manufacturers and
the unstoppable
efficiency of the VW group.

Sales struggled, and it needed
to redefine itself.

Tapping into the demand for
increased efficiency, it

hedged its bets on
electric power.

And in 2009 Renault CEO Carlos
Ghosn said, we're putting our

chips, and we're putting our
investment, and we're putting

our efforts behind this belief
that now is the time.
So now is the time.

This is the new Renault Twizy,
with it's 17-horsepower

electric motor weighing 465
kilograms and, wait for it,

capable of 0 to 28 miles
an hour in 6.1 seconds.

Firing up the Twizy is not
an ordinary exercise.

You put on this belt here, then
you have a fourth point

belt that comes over
like that.

It just feels like you're not
actually ready to go anywhere.

Then you take your key, which
looks just like a sort of Clio

key, but it's got
nothing on it.
No markings at all.

All the sci-fi outside,
and you get a rather
ordinary-looking key.

You plug it in the hole, like
this, and you turn it around.

Your dashboard lights up and
tells you that you've got a
bit of battery left.
You then press D for drive.

You try and undo the rather
awkward hand brake.
And then there's no noise.
Oh, a beep saying, go.
And that's it.
Completely silent.

It is, by any stretch,
very strange.

Then you just pull away with
so little noise, the whole
thing seems a bit bizarre.
OK, start from the top.
It's not very fast.

0 to 28 miles an hour in
6.1 seconds might sound

impressive, and it does kind of
get going, but by the time

you reach about 35 miles an
hour, 40 miles an hour, it

doesn't really want to
accelerate an awful lot more.
That doesn't worry me, though.

I can now understand why they've
launched this car in a
[INAUDIBLE]

because it's going to hoover up
car sales or scooter sales

in the Mediterranean holiday
destinations.
It's perfect for here.
I'm open-sided.

I can smell these wonderful
whatever-they-are, eucalypt,
or conifers outside.
I can smell the island.

It's just very, very
pleasant knocking
along inside this car.

Unexpected things
about the Twizy.
It's got masses of grip.

It's only got those skinny
little tires, but good lord.

I keep finding myself
thinking--

can I go flat out around
this corner.

It's a classic [INAUDIBLE]
car in that respect.

You get in and you want
to just see how fast
you can go in it.

I would say that it's not
going to increase the
frequency of crashes in holiday
destinations by teenagers.

But it's probably just going
to cause slightly different

types of accidents,
that's all.

The steering is unassisted and
light and actually, really
rather nice.

The front end wants
to push a bit.

They've obviously had to put
some understeering in the car

to make sure that I don't go
out and do massive skids.
Although we did try.
Watch this.
Right?

These roads are very smooth, and
it feels quite busy to me.

So I suspect it could be quite
rough on a coarse UK road.

But let's get to the
crux of this, guys.

Who is going to buy one of
these are live in a rural
environment?
They just aren't.

This is a car, I think,
with two purposes.

One, the rental market, as I've
said, in Europe in hot
destinations nations.
And also, center of town.

And to all you people in America
watching this, you

have to understand that a lot
of we strange Europeans live
in crowded towns.

And there's so much congestion
that you can't get anywhere.

And the cost of fuel
is ridiculous.

So the idea of something that
you can just plug in and

charge and then knock around
town for an hour or so and

then come back again, that's
quite appealing.

OK, the claimed range of this
car, best case scenario, is

about 60 miles, 100
kilometers or so.

When you get in it, it displays
about 50 or 60
kilometers range.

If you then stay around town
and drive it at its worst,

least efficient, let's say, with
no regenerative breaking

at all, it will stay at
around that mark.

If you then drive the thing
absolutely flat out, you'll

probably get about 30 miles
from a battery charge.

However, if you're out on the
road using the braking,

staying off the throttle,
coasting down hills-- that's a

fun bit, that is, because you
find yourself doing massive

late-breaking maneuvers into
tighter turns, hanging on,

hanging on, hanging on so
that you can get as much

regenerative force into
it as possible.

If you're doing that, well,
you can eke the thing out
quite a lot.

And it's quite fun hanging
onto the range meter and

seeing how much you can
squeeze from it.

As for charging, well, in the
UK, if you live in the UK and

you plug this thing in
do you know what?
[INAUDIBLE]

it's going to take you 12 hours
to get your next 60
miles out of it.

So really, you need to be
involved in a shortish commute

to make the things work
on a daily basis.

There are two downsides to not
having any internal combustion
engine noise, then.

First of all, unlike the last
electric car I drove, which

was, I think, the Tesla,
this has got quite a
lot of gearbox noise.
Ready?

It sorts of whines and does
sound like a golf buggy.

That's not the nicest
noise, OK.

The other downside is that, when
you're mooching around

town and driving slowly, as
you do quite a lot in the

Twizy, you hear all the other
crud that comes with a car
that you don't want.

If you pick a stone up, it just
goes [RHYTHMIC TAPPING].

If you just brake, the
caliper might grab a
disc a bit too long.

And it just sort of goes
[GRATING SOUND].

You just get these
nasty noises.

And the Twizy, to me, is a bit
of a collection of slightly
nasty noises.

It's sort of fingernails
down blackboard and all
that sort of stuff.
It's not that pleasant.

But there's no doubting
that it's quite a
joyful little thing.

I personally feel that you can't
watch more than a few
minutes of this.
I can tell you how good it is.

But you can't listen to that
bloody whining noise for too
long, can you?
So do you know what?

Renault makes some other
very exciting cars.

So thank you for sitting
through the Twizy.
Well done, Twizy.

You're more than good enough for
what you want to do, and
you're quite funky.

But Renault make much more
exciting cars, like this one.

You know, when it comes
to Renault, I
quite like the present.

The Twizy may be a glimpse of
the future, but the current

clear Renault Sport 200, with a
cup chassis that I'm driving

at the moment, is one of the
great small, fast cars.
It's just awesome.

And I have to say if I've got
to start doing videos on

electric cars, every single
video's got to have some

action with something
like this in it.

Because it is just
an absolute riot.

It's got an RS badge on the
front, and it fully, fully
deserves it.

It's just a lightweight,
very focused hatchback.

It's got a beam axle at the
back, so it's not the last

word in sophistication,
but just--

it just absolutely cuts to
the essence of what fun
driving is all about.

200 horsepower, under
1300 kilograms.
You have to rev it.

You have to rev, and rev, and
rev. You just row this little
lever around.

You keep thinking, it
can't rev anymore.
And it does.
[INAUDIBLE]

it's a bit coarse, but
it gets the job done.

There's quite a lot to celebrate
about the Twizy.
I'll give you that.
It's an electric vehicle.

It has much, much lower
emissions than this car.

Electric cars are, whether
we like it or not,
a part of our future.

But it's completely
a-emotional.

And you only remind yourself
just how a-emotional the car

is by driving something
like this.

This is a proper little
European hothead.

It's the kind of car that
I was brought up on.

It's the kind of car that I feel
very passionate about.

Because it provides a relatively
affordable entry

point to having fun in cars, to
learning how to drive cars,
understanding them.

But I'm not sure that
these electric
vehicles can offer that.

I'm not sure that the electric
vehicle really
offers that as a future.
It's completely noiseless.

This car's just puffing
away behind me.
The exhaust is making noise.
I'm in control of it.

OK, it's not that efficient, but
it doesn't feel like I'm

really, really ruining
the world from here.

It feels like I'm being
quite responsible.
Well, for [INAUDIBLE].

So from a media perspective,
yeah.

The Twizy's slightly put the
writing on the wall for me.

If I've got to test electric
cars and generate exciting

content for you guys to watch,
how the hell do I do it if the

thing makes no noise and
doesn't do much?
I'm kind of out of a job.

If anyone's got any ideas out
there, can you write to me on

Twitter, @MikeyHarris, or leave
a comment on this video
because I'm a bit worried.

But it does mean that, in the
meantime, I'm going to enjoy

doing this for as
long as I can.

title: Renault Twizy Review: Are Electric Cars Any Good? - /CHRIS HARRS ON CARS

comments.text:
*Hilarious: But Good: Renault Twizy Electric Car Review By Chris Harris*

comments.text:
Rev Head,   The world is changing and the electric car is proof of coming 
change.  There was a time when the roads were empty and you could do as you 
pleased.  now the roads are very crowded and drivers must all drive the 
same way at the same speed. Sorry,  you are out of date, passé,  floppy

robots will drive cars and you will program the robot.  If you think you 
will be able to compete with robots for precision driving for hour after

comments.author: Simon Tsoi

comments.text:
I do not get the idea of Twizzy. Yes, it is small and efficient way of 
transportation, but it has not weather protection, no safety, no power... 
It has a passenger seat, but what is the point? you cannot talk to your 
passenger and s/he will not feel better of from taking a bus to the same 
destination. And please do not compare it to scooters. Scooters are great 
fun, way cheaper and actually make more sense. For the same money, buy a 
second hand Twingo or Smart car. ﻿
comments.author: Grigolly

comments.text:
I'll explain. Twizy is like a scooter but it is much safer. You cant hear 
when wearing a helmet like ever.  But you can hear passenger if you drive 
up to city speed, 40km/h.
Also twizy is more convinient than a scooter. You  do have more weather 
protection than with scooter. Also twizy is designed so that you do not 
take your clothes off when you enter the vehicle (same on the scooter). So 
if it is raining you wear stuff and not only t-shirt. It is not highway 
friendly but 50cc scooters are even worse at that point. So twizy is for 
people who want to be safe and still ride something like scooter.

comments.author: alex li

comments.text:
Really car companies and enthusiasts have to be conservative with the 
motors they put in EVs cos the batteries while a lot better still have a 
way to go.  It would actually be relatively easy to make an ev with 1600 
horesepower and more than 3000 nm of torque the thing would just destroy 
it's batteries and run dead in a minute or two. Petrol and diesel has a 
much higher energy density than even the best batteries. Once batteries 
surpass that (if they ever do) Internal combustion is as good as gone. 
Still  while yet though. ﻿

comments.text:

comments.text:
That is understood, but no other country in the history of the earth has 
ever attempted or made claim to the fact that they wish to be called 
"America" or have the word "America" included in their country. There is no 
disrespect implied in referring to the United States of America as just 
"america" because you would have to be a complete moron to not understand 
that's it's referring to the USA rather than basically the entire Western 
Hemisphere. Again, take the fucking stick out of your ass. It's not a 
fucking misconception because nobody goes "oh wait did you mean the USA or 
both continents?" because nobody possesses that little logic of context. 
The "American continent" doesn't exist. The "American continent" you are 
referring to is actually comprised of two separate continents which 
contains many different groups of nations which are all referred to 
separately with their own fairly unique names. If you can't understand the 
geographical location (nation, continent, etc.) in question just based on 
the context of whatever it is you're talking about then you have a personal 
problem.

comments.author: Jason Cardoz

comments.text:
No emissions from the electric? Hmmmm - Lets figure that out. A petrol 
vehicle burns petrol, and an electric vehicle burns coal since that is 
where the majority of electricity comes from. It gets worse. Pumping 
electricity into a battery is only around 80% efficient. In other words a 
little more coal is required to be burned in order to charge. Also, 
extracting energy from a battery to motivate the vehicle, is only 80% 
efficient, so even more coal is required. Essentially, it would take 1.56 
units of coal to get 1 unit of vehicle usage. You would be better off with 
a coal burning vehicle and steam.

On the other hand - Petrol usage is way more efficient. I like electric 
vehicles, but I also understand that they actually create more polution 
based on the efficiencies, AND the polution required to make batteries.﻿
comments.author: Alan Williams

comments.text:
And you are the inventor of loss-free, zero emission, cheap to build and 
sustainable energy supply, am I right? the goal is not to build the most 
efficient but the least pollutant power plant so that we can live on planet 
earth for more than the next 100 years.
comments.author: NitroTom91

comments.text:
+NitroTom91 So for every 100 watts of electrical energy you pump into 
water, you only get 30 watts of hydrogen energy. Even more losses - This is 
why no one is producing Hydrogen from Water for the masses.
I don't see any issue with rare earth magnets. We produce them all of the 
time.

Face it - If you could do what you believe is sensible, then you would. 
Fact is, you don't and neither does anyone else.
comments.author: Alan Williams

comments.text:
+Pedro Gordinho You are exactly right in all your points. The only thing I 
want to add is the problem with neodymium magnets being required in the 
process of producing and using electricity for transportation. 
I think the best way would be to use the wind turbines and other power 
plants to make hydrogen out of water (for example sea water). That way we 
could use our infrastructure of gas pipelines and all that to use it as 
fuel and to heat our homes. It would be the cheapest and fastest way to get 
almost infinite energy storage capabilities. We can even burn it in our 
cars by just replacing the tank and fuel lines. But as you say, the oil 
companies don't want that to happen.
comments.author: NitroTom91

comments.text:
Ever heard about wind turbines and solar panels?. In my country they give 
us about 70 % of our electricity. And for the petrol vehicle, let´s see... 
the gigantic oil tanker brings the oil to your country (I can't imagine how 
much fuel it spends) then the oil is pumped to the refineries (more fuel or 
electricity)  then the refinery spends energy and makes pollution to 
fabricate the fuel that we use, then the fuels are taken by trucks to the 
local gas station, then you spend a lot of money and fuel to go to the gas 
station and return. I honestly believe that electric vehicles are far 
better than petrol ones. The only problem with electric vehicles is the 
fact that the oil companies are not going to allow car manufactures to sell 
affordable electric cars as long has there is oil to burn.
comments.author: Pedro Gordinho

comments.text:
Chris excellent! Your questions are brilliant, I have a passion for cars, 
it's difficult to gauge how the future will be emotionally without the 
combustion engine. I wouldn't say electric vehicles lack fun at all, the 
twizy is great, direct steering, simple, light so many petrols just lack 
this basic fun factor. But you are right the noise, the smell, the 
vibrations and manual control of the engine; gearbox and skills required to 
control is not the same. I do love electric cars to drive though, the 
fluid, beautifully smooth delivery cannot be matched, nor can we ignore the 
damn torque, instantaneous acceleration of electric, in reality of 'normal' 
journeys quiet is just what most of us want! I guess we need to just face 
the future, in the meantime lets enjoy the petrol we have left. Keep up the 
good work, in the meantime test the Model-S as I'm bursting at the seams to 
drive one, and with your honesty and passion I'm waiting for your opinion. ﻿
comments.author: advancedinstructor

you've ever been in a Tesla you will quickly realize that if they can make 
electric cars like this compete with M5s and AMG Benzes for less or around 
the same money NOW...image 5-10 years from now.

going on your motorbike. It's not like it won't function when it rains. The

get a roof, doors or optional full doors on a motorbike (excluding the BMW 
C1). And not to mention about safety...

comments.text:
That's true it takes about 1/3 of the energy just to extract the petroleum. 
In fact electric vehicles don't even need batteries either.MIT is working

comments.author: m9078jk3

comments.text:
To add to m9078jk3's point, a lot of people forget that fact that Gasoline 
extraction, transportation, refinement, storage, and distribution process 
involves a combination of burning more fuels, and electricity (especially 
refinement). If all of that is added to the final CO2 emissions at the 
tailpipe on your car, it is a whole lot more than just that 19.4 lbs. And, 
like you pointed out, power plants can be cleaner, depending on location. 
So, overall, Electric vehicles do make more sense.
comments.author: pogularocky

comments.text:
Well a gallon of gasoline releases about 19.4 pounds of Carbon Dioxide 
(proven greenhouse gas) into the atmosphere when combined with atmospheric 
oxygen.As to electrical power sources it's quite variable as to total 
carbon emissions release.. Obviously if the electricity is obtained from 
Coal Power plants there are substantial emissions.Where I reside in my 
locale we get about 93% of our electricity from vastly cleaner 
hydroelectric sources with under 2% from Coal Fired electric plants.
comments.author: m9078jk3

comments.text:
Hey, well it looks an interesting way on comparing not only resource 
efficiency, but also can give you an idea on how polluant can each 
automotive method be, since only a little part of the electricity is 
obtained by recyclable energy sources. I think it's a strong argument for 
all the controversy on this issue, and I think should be between the top 
comments of this video. Thanks, for few times in youtube, for your useful 
words! ;)

comments.text: Allright, thanks for the info ;)
comments.author: inaki1213

comments.text: 3.5 hour charge time is from a standard household plug.
comments.author: Quickblood1

comments.text:
The ELF only has a 480 watt-hour battery.It claims a range of 30 
miles.However from what I've also discovered is that this figure is derived 
from considering an average adult rider on a electric bike with half the 
range powered by human and half by electric power.So the true MPGe of the 
ELF under just electric propulsion alone is half that (under ideal 
conditions level terrain).With my traveled route-(somewhat hilly terrain) I 
would likely get a electric powered range of just 7.5 miles or so.
comments.author: m9078jk3

comments.text:
You can calculate the figures using a 33.4 Kilowatt hours electrical 
equivalency (energy content) to 1 gallon of gasoline.Divide by the energy 
storage of the battery (6.1 Kilowatt-hours- Wikipedia Renault Twizy) and 
then multiply by the average range.(50 miles-source Renault Twizy).This 
will give you the MPGe.(the small e means equivalency).I perhaps should 
have used the homologated 62 mile range instead MPGe figure would be 
higher. Range varies depending upon terrain,road conditions etc.
comments.author: m9078jk3

comments.text:
How are these figures calculated? Could you please share the source(s) you 
got this info from? ;)
